Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the number of doctors who have opted out of Obamacare exchanges by stating that "Over 214,000 doctors" have done so, without providing sufficient evidence to support this claim.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as it does not provide specific data or sources to back up the claim that over 214,000 doctors have opted out of Obamacare exchanges.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that doctors opting out of Obamacare exchanges means they are refusing patients with coverage bought on Affordable Care Act marketplaces, without providing evidence to support this assumption.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim does not consider alternative explanations for doctors opting out of Obamacare exchanges, such as insurance providers choosing not to include certain doctors or health groups in policies created for the marketplaces.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the Affordable Care Act requires essentially everyone to have insurance, and doctors can choose not to participate in the networks of policies purchased on exchanges.
Falters at times: The claim falters at times by presenting conflicting information and not providing a clear explanation of the reasons why doctors are opting out of Obamacare exchanges.
Understate: There is no evidence of understating bias in the provided claim.
